Article.ArticleTitle: Rural vehicle emission as an important driver for the variations of summertime tropospheric ozone in the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region during 2014-2019.

AbstractText: Tropospheric ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) pollution is increasing in the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei (BTH) region despite a significant decline in atmospheric fine aerosol particles (PM<sub>2.5</sub>) in recent years. However, the intrinsic reason for the elevation of the regional O<sub>3</sub> is still unclear. In this study, we analyzed the spatio-temporal variations of tropospheric O<sub>3</sub> and relevant pollutants (PM<sub>2.5</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, and CO) in the BTH region based on monitoring data from the China Ministry of Ecology and Environment during the period of 2014-2019. The results showed that summertime O<sub>3</sub> concentrations were constant in Beijing (BJ, 0.06 µg/(m<sup>3</sup>•year)) but increased significantly in Tianjin (TJ, 9.09 µg/(m<sup>3</sup>•year)) and Hebei (HB, 6.06 µg/(m<sup>3</sup>•year)). Distinct O<sub>3</sub> trends between Beijing and other cities in BTH could not be attributed to the significant decrease in PM<sub>2.5</sub> (from -5.08 to -6.32 µg/(m<sup>3</sup>•year)) and CO (from -0.053 to -0.090 mg/(m<sup>3</sup>•year)) because their decreasing rates were approximately the same in all the cities. The relatively stable O<sub>3</sub> concentrations during the investigating period in BJ may be attributed to a faster decreasing rate of NO<sub>2</sub> (BJ: -2.55 µg/(m<sup>3</sup>•year); TJ: -1.16 µg/(m<sup>3</sup>•year); HB: -1.34 µg/(m<sup>3</sup>•year)), indicating that the continued reduction of NO<sub>x</sub> will be an effective mitigation strategy for reducing regional O<sub>3</sub> pollution. Significant positive correlations were found between daily maximum 8 hr average (MDA8) O<sub>3</sub> concentrations and vehicle population and highway freight transportation in HB. Therefore, we speculate that the increase in rural NO<sub>x</sub> emissions due to the increase in vehicle emissions in the vast rural areas around HB greatly accelerates regional O<sub>3</sub> formation, accounting for the significant increasing trends of O<sub>3</sub> in HB.
